title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Load readxl and tidyverse library.

library(readxl)

Warning: package 'readxl' was built under R version 4.4.2

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.4.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Load in white-wine excel data.

white_wine <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx")
white_wine

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 2              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
 3              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 4              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 5              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 6              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 7              62               0.32          0.16              7       0.045
 8               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 9              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
10              81               0.22          0.43              1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Extract column names from second sheet in excel file and use to rename the tibble’s column names.

wine_col_names <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx",
                             sheet = excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx")[2])
colnames(white_wine) <- as.matrix(wine_col_names)

Add column called type to indicate these wines are white

white_wine <- white_wine |>
  mutate(type = "white")

white_wine

# A tibble: 4,898 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Load readr library.

library(readr)

Load in read wine data.

red_wine <- read_delim("../red-wine.csv", delim = ";")

Rows: 1599 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ";"
dbl (12): fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlo...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

red_wine

# A tibble: 1,599 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7.4               0.7           0                 1.9     0.076
 2             7.8               0.88          0                 2.6     0.098
 3             7.8               0.76          0.04              2.3     0.092
 4            11.2               0.28          0.56              1.9     0.075
 5             7.4               0.7           0                 1.9     0.076
 6             7.4               0.66          0                 1.8     0.075
 7             7.9               0.6           0.06              1.6     0.069
 8             7.3               0.65          0                 1.2     0.065
 9             7.8               0.58          0.02              2       0.073
10             7.5               0.5           0.36              6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Replace the variable names with the same ones as above.

colnames(red_wine) <- as.matrix(wine_col_names)

red_wine <- red_wine |>
  mutate(type = "red")

red_wine

# A tibble: 1,599 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 2           7.8             0.88        0               2.6     0.098
 3           7.8             0.76        0.04            2.3     0.092
 4          11.2             0.28        0.56            1.9     0.075
 5           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 6           7.4             0.66        0               1.8     0.075
 7           7.9             0.6         0.06            1.6     0.069
 8           7.3             0.65        0               1.2     0.065
 9           7.8             0.58        0.02            2       0.073
10           7.5             0.5         0.36            6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Combine two data sets into one data set.

wine_data <- bind_rows(white_wine, red_wine)
wine_data

# A tibble: 6,497 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 6,487 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Filter combined data set for wines with quality greater than 6.5 and alcohol less than 132.

wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132)

# A tibble: 1,206 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1            66             0.16        0.4             1.5     0.044
 2            66             0.17        0.38            1.5     0.032
 3            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 4            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 5            64             0.31        0.38            2.9     0.038
 6            68             0.26        0.42            1.7     0.049
 7            72             0.32        0.36            2       0.033
 8            74             0.18        0.31            1.4     0.058
 9            66             0.25        0.29            1.1     0.068
10            62             0.16        0.33            1.1     0.057
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Continuing the chain, the data is sorted from highest to lowstest quality (descending order).

wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality))

# A tibble: 1,206 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45           10.6     0.035
 2            66             0.36        0.29            1.6     0.021
 3            74             0.24        0.36            2       0.031
 4            69             0.36        0.34            4.2     0.018
 5            71             0.26        0.49            2.2     0.032
 6            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 7            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 8            68             0.26        0.42            1.7     0.049
 9            67             0.23        0.31            2.1     0.046
10            67             0.23        0.31            2.1     0.046
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Continuing the chain, we select the variables containing “acid”, alcohol, type, and quality.

wine_data |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) 

# A tibble: 1,206 × 6
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol type  quality
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104 white       9
 2            66             0.36        0.29     124 white       9
 3            74             0.24        0.36     125 white       9
 4            69             0.36        0.34     127 white       9
 5            71             0.26        0.49     129 white       9
 6            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8
 7            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8
 8            68             0.26        0.42     105 white       8
 9            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8
10            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8
# ℹ 1,196 more rows


Final addition to chain, for each value of the quality variable, calculate the mean and standard deviation of the alcohol as new columns.

wine_data |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  group_by(quality) |>
  mutate(across(alcohol, list(mean = mean, sd = sd)))

# A tibble: 1,206 × 8
# Groups:   quality [3]
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol type  quality alcohol_mean
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>        <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104 white       9        122. 
 2            66             0.36        0.29     124 white       9        122. 
 3            74             0.24        0.36     125 white       9        122. 
 4            69             0.36        0.34     127 white       9        122. 
 5            71             0.26        0.49     129 white       9        122. 
 6            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8         94.1
 7            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8         94.1
 8            68             0.26        0.42     105 white       8         94.1
 9            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8         94.1
10            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8         94.1
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: alcohol_sd <dbl>

title: Conceptual Questions
text:
The relative path would be “../MyData.csv”


Some of the major benefits of using R projects are being able to store all the related files such as scripts, figures, and reports in a organized way. Additionally, it is integrated with version control systems like git, which make collaboration and sharing very easy.


Git is the actual version control system that allows you to push updated versions of your projects and track changes from older versions of your project. Github is the platform in which you access/view your work via a repository.


A difference between data frames and tibbles is that the unique tidyverse functions are built to work on tibbles rather than data frames. Another difference is the defualt print for tibbles contain more information than when printing dataframes. Tibbles print the number of observations, the number of columns, and condenses the output to the first 10 rows to prevent excessive output.


as_tibble(iris) |> select(starts_with(“Petal”), Species) |> filter(Petal.Length < 1.55) |> arrange(Species)

title: Homework 4
text:
By Ella Gruchacz
This is my landing page for homework 4!
The following pages contain my answers for tasks 1, 2, and 3.

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Load tidyverse library.

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.4.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Load in glass data with a comma deliminator and add appropiate column names.

glass_data <- read_delim("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/glass.data", delim = ",", col_names = c("Id", "RI","Na", "Mg","Al","Si","K","Ca","Ba","Fe", "Type_of_glass"))

Rows: 214 Columns: 11
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (11): Id, RI, Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, Ba, Fe, Type_of_glass

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glass_data

# A tibble: 214 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>         <dbl>
 1     1  1.52  13.6  4.49  1.1   71.8  0.06  8.75     0  0                1
 2     2  1.52  13.9  3.6   1.36  72.7  0.48  7.83     0  0                1
 3     3  1.52  13.5  3.55  1.54  73.0  0.39  7.78     0  0                1
 4     4  1.52  13.2  3.69  1.29  72.6  0.57  8.22     0  0                1
 5     5  1.52  13.3  3.62  1.24  73.1  0.55  8.07     0  0                1
 6     6  1.52  12.8  3.61  1.62  73.0  0.64  8.07     0  0.26             1
 7     7  1.52  13.3  3.6   1.14  73.1  0.58  8.17     0  0                1
 8     8  1.52  13.2  3.61  1.05  73.2  0.57  8.24     0  0                1
 9     9  1.52  14.0  3.58  1.37  72.1  0.56  8.3      0  0                1
10    10  1.52  13    3.6   1.36  73.0  0.57  8.4      0  0.11             1
# ℹ 204 more rows


Overwrite the Type_of_glass that replaces the number indicator with the description. Continuing the chain, keeping only the observations where the Fe is less than 0.2 and Type_of_glass is “tableware” or “headlamps”.

glass_data |>
        mutate(Type_of_glass =
            ifelse(Type_of_glass == 1,"building_windows_float_processed",
                  ifelse(Type_of_glass == 2,
                         "building_windows_non_float_processed",
                        ifelse(Type_of_glass == 3, 
                               "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
                            ifelse(Type_of_glass == 4,
                                   "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
                                   ifelse(Type_of_glass == 5, 
                                          "containers",
                                          ifelse(Type_of_glass == 6,
                                                 "tableware",
                                                 ifelse(Type_of_glass == 7,
                                                        "headlamps","error")
                                                 ))))))) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2 & Type_of_glass == c("tableware", "headlamps"))

# A tibble: 20 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        
 1   177  1.52  14    2.39  1.56  72.4  0     9.57  0     0    tableware    
 2   179  1.52  14.5  2.24  1.62  72.4  0     9.26  0     0    tableware    
 3   181  1.51  14.4  1.74  1.54  74.6  0     7.59  0     0    tableware    
 4   183  1.52  14.2  0     2.09  72.7  0    10.9   0     0    tableware    
 5   185  1.51  17.4  0     0.34  75.4  0     6.65  0     0    tableware    
 6   186  1.51  13.7  3.2   1.81  72.8  1.76  5.43  1.19  0    headlamps    
 7   188  1.52  13.4  3.34  1.23  72.4  0.6   8.83  0     0    headlamps    
 8   190  1.52  15.8  1.83  1.31  70.4  0.31  8.61  1.68  0    headlamps    
 9   192  1.52  14.8  0     2.38  73.3  0     8.76  0.64  0.09 headlamps    
10   194  1.52  14.8  0     2     73.0  0     8.53  1.59  0.08 headlamps    
11   196  1.52  14.1  0     2.68  73.4  0.08  9.07  0.61  0.05 headlamps    
12   198  1.52  14.7  0     2.34  73.3  0     8.95  0.66  0    headlamps    
13   200  1.52  15.0  0     2.51  73.0  0.05  8.83  0.53  0    headlamps    
14   202  1.52  12.0  0     1.19  75.2  2.7   8.93  0     0    headlamps    
15   204  1.52  14.8  0     1.99  73.1  0     8.28  1.71  0    headlamps    
16   206  1.52  15.0  0     1.8   73.0  0     8.61  1.55  0    headlamps    
17   208  1.52  14.4  0     1.82  72.9  1.41  6.47  2.88  0    headlamps    
18   210  1.52  14.1  0     2.88  72.6  0.08  9.18  1.06  0    headlamps    
19   212  1.52  14.4  0     2.02  73.4  0     8.44  1.64  0    headlamps    
20   214  1.52  14.2  0     2.08  73.4  0     8.62  1.67  0    headlamps    


First row of data to inspect
ADT1_YEAST 0.58 0.61 0.47 0.13 0.50 0.00 0.48 0.22 MIT
Using the width of the data column we can read in the data and assign appropiate column names.

yeast_data <- read_fwf("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/yeast.data", 
                       fwf_widths(c(12,6,6,6,6,6,6,6,6,6),
                       col_names = c("seq_name", "mcg", "gvh", "alm", "mit", "erl", "pox","vac","nuc","class")))

Rows: 1484 Columns: 10
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

chr (2): seq_name, class
dbl (8): mcg, gvh, alm, mit, erl, pox, vac, nuc

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Manipulate the yeast data by starting a chain and removing the columns seq_name and nuc

yeast_data |> 
  select(c(-"seq_name", -"nuc"))

# A tibble: 1,484 × 8
     mcg   gvh   alm   mit   erl   pox   vac class
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
 1  0.58  0.61  0.47  0.13   0.5   0    0.48 MIT  
 2  0.43  0.67  0.48  0.27   0.5   0    0.53 MIT  
 3  0.64  0.62  0.49  0.15   0.5   0    0.53 MIT  
 4  0.58  0.44  0.57  0.13   0.5   0    0.54 NUC  
 5  0.42  0.44  0.48  0.54   0.5   0    0.48 MIT  
 6  0.51  0.4   0.56  0.17   0.5   0.5  0.49 CYT  
 7  0.5   0.54  0.48  0.65   0.5   0    0.53 MIT  
 8  0.48  0.45  0.59  0.2    0.5   0    0.58 NUC  
 9  0.55  0.5   0.66  0.36   0.5   0    0.49 MIT  
10  0.4   0.39  0.6   0.15   0.5   0    0.58 CYT  
# ℹ 1,474 more rows


Add columns for the mean and median of each numeric column at each class grouping. Note the across function allows us to the same action (make and mean and median column) to multiple columns (the numeric ones).

yeast_data |> 
  select(c(-"seq_name", -"nuc")) |>
  group_by(class) |>
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), list(mean = mean, md = median)))

# A tibble: 1,484 × 22
# Groups:   class [10]
     mcg   gvh   alm   mit   erl   pox   vac class mcg_mean mcg_md gvh_mean
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>
 1  0.58  0.61  0.47  0.13   0.5   0    0.48 MIT      0.521   0.51    0.533
 2  0.43  0.67  0.48  0.27   0.5   0    0.53 MIT      0.521   0.51    0.533
 3  0.64  0.62  0.49  0.15   0.5   0    0.53 MIT      0.521   0.51    0.533
 4  0.58  0.44  0.57  0.13   0.5   0    0.54 NUC      0.452   0.45    0.456
 5  0.42  0.44  0.48  0.54   0.5   0    0.48 MIT      0.521   0.51    0.533
 6  0.51  0.4   0.56  0.17   0.5   0.5  0.49 CYT      0.481   0.48    0.470
 7  0.5   0.54  0.48  0.65   0.5   0    0.53 MIT      0.521   0.51    0.533
 8  0.48  0.45  0.59  0.2    0.5   0    0.58 NUC      0.452   0.45    0.456
 9  0.55  0.5   0.66  0.36   0.5   0    0.49 MIT      0.521   0.51    0.533
10  0.4   0.39  0.6   0.15   0.5   0    0.58 CYT      0.481   0.48    0.470
# ℹ 1,474 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: gvh_md <dbl>, alm_mean <dbl>, alm_md <dbl>,
#   mit_mean <dbl>, mit_md <dbl>, erl_mean <dbl>, erl_md <dbl>, pox_mean <dbl>,
#   pox_md <dbl>, vac_mean <dbl>, vac_md <dbl>

title: Conceptual Questions
text:
If your working directory is myfolder/homework/, what relative path would you specify to get the file located at myfolder/MyData.csv? The relative path would be “../MyData.csv”


What are the major bebifits of using R projects? Some of the major benefits of using R projects are being able to store all the related files such as scripts, figures, and reports in a organized way. Additionally, it is integrated with version control systems like git, which make collaboration and sharing very easy.


What is git and what is github? Git is the actual version control system that allows you to push updated versions of your projects and track changes from older versions of your project. Github is the platform in which you access/view your work via a repository.


What are the two main differences between tibble and a data frame? A difference between data frames and tibbles is that the unique tidyverse functions are built to work on tibbles rather than data frames. Another difference is the defualt print for tibbles contain more information than when printing dataframes. Tibbles print the number of observations, the number of columns, and condenses the output to the first 10 rows to prevent excessive output.


Rewrite the following nested function using BaseR chaining operator:


arrange(filter(select(as_tibble(iris), starts_with(“Petal”), Species), Petal.Length < 1.55), Species)


as_tibble(iris) |> select(starts_with(“Petal”), Species) |> filter(Petal.Length < 1.55) |> arrange(Species)

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Load tidyverse library.

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.4.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Load in glass data with a comma deliminator and add appropiate column names.

glass_data <- read_delim("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/glass.data", delim = ",", col_names = c("Id", "RI","Na", "Mg","Al","Si","K","Ca","Ba","Fe", "Type_of_glass"))

Rows: 214 Columns: 11
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (11): Id, RI, Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, Ba, Fe, Type_of_glass

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glass_data

# A tibble: 214 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>         <dbl>
 1     1  1.52  13.6  4.49  1.1   71.8  0.06  8.75     0  0                1
 2     2  1.52  13.9  3.6   1.36  72.7  0.48  7.83     0  0                1
 3     3  1.52  13.5  3.55  1.54  73.0  0.39  7.78     0  0                1
 4     4  1.52  13.2  3.69  1.29  72.6  0.57  8.22     0  0                1
 5     5  1.52  13.3  3.62  1.24  73.1  0.55  8.07     0  0                1
 6     6  1.52  12.8  3.61  1.62  73.0  0.64  8.07     0  0.26             1
 7     7  1.52  13.3  3.6   1.14  73.1  0.58  8.17     0  0                1
 8     8  1.52  13.2  3.61  1.05  73.2  0.57  8.24     0  0                1
 9     9  1.52  14.0  3.58  1.37  72.1  0.56  8.3      0  0                1
10    10  1.52  13    3.6   1.36  73.0  0.57  8.4      0  0.11             1
# ℹ 204 more rows


Overwrite the Type_of_glass that replaces the number indicator with the description. Continuing the chain, keeping only the observations where the Fe is less than 0.2 and Type_of_glass is “tableware” or “headlamps”.

glass_data |>
        mutate(Type_of_glass =
            ifelse(Type_of_glass == 1,"building_windows_float_processed",
                  ifelse(Type_of_glass == 2,
                         "building_windows_non_float_processed",
                        ifelse(Type_of_glass == 3, 
                               "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
                            ifelse(Type_of_glass == 4,
                                   "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
                                   ifelse(Type_of_glass == 5, 
                                          "containers",
                                          ifelse(Type_of_glass == 6,
                                                 "tableware",
                                                 ifelse(Type_of_glass == 7,
                                                        "headlamps","error")
                                                 ))))))) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2 & Type_of_glass == c("tableware", "headlamps"))

# A tibble: 20 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        
 1   177  1.52  14    2.39  1.56  72.4  0     9.57  0     0    tableware

 3   181  1.51  14.4  1.74  1.54  74.6  0     7.59  0     0    tableware    
 4   183  1.52  14.2  0     2.09  72.7  0    10.9   0     0    tableware

10   194  1.52  14.8  0     2     73.0  0     8.53  1.59  0.08 headlamps    
11   196  1.52  14.1  0     2.68  73.4  0.08  9.07  0.61  0.05 headlamps    
12   198  1.52  14.7  0     2.34  73.3  0     8.95  0.66  0    headlamps

14   202  1.52  12.0  0     1.19  75.2  2.7   8.93  0     0    headlamps

16   206  1.52  15.0  0     1.8   73.0  0     8.61  1.55  0    headlamps    
17   208  1.52  14.4  0     1.82  72.9  1.41  6.47  2.88  0    headlamps    
18   210  1.52  14.1  0     2.88  72.6  0.08  9.18  1.06  0    headlamps    
19   212  1.52  14.4  0     2.02  73.4  0     8.44  1.64  0    headlamps    
20   214  1.52  14.2  0     2.08  73.4  0     8.62  1.67  0    headlamps    


First row of data to inspect
ADT1_YEAST 0.58 0.61 0.47 0.13 0.50 0.00 0.48 0.22 MIT
Using the width of the data column we can read in the data and assign appropiate column names.

yeast_data <- read_fwf("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/yeast.data", 
                       fwf_widths(c(12,6,6,6,6,6,6,6,6,6),
                       col_names = c("seq_name", "mcg", "gvh", "alm", "mit", "erl", "pox","vac","nuc","class")))

Rows: 1484 Columns: 10
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

chr (2): seq_name, class
dbl (8): mcg, gvh, alm, mit, erl, pox, vac, nuc

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Manipulate the yeast data by starting a chain and removing the columns seq_name and nuc

yeast_data |> 
  select(c(-"seq_name", -"nuc"))

# A tibble: 1,484 × 8
     mcg   gvh   alm   mit   erl   pox   vac class
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
 1  0.58  0.61  0.47  0.13   0.5   0    0.48 MIT  
 2  0.43  0.67  0.48  0.27   0.5   0    0.53 MIT  
 3  0.64  0.62  0.49  0.15   0.5   0    0.53 MIT  
 4  0.58  0.44  0.57  0.13   0.5   0    0.54 NUC  
 5  0.42  0.44  0.48  0.54   0.5   0    0.48 MIT  
 6  0.51  0.4   0.56  0.17   0.5   0.5  0.49 CYT  
 7  0.5   0.54  0.48  0.65   0.5   0    0.53 MIT  
 8  0.48  0.45  0.59  0.2    0.5   0    0.58 NUC  
 9  0.55  0.5   0.66  0.36   0.5   0    0.49 MIT  
10  0.4   0.39  0.6   0.15   0.5   0    0.58 CYT  
# ℹ 1,474 more rows


Add columns for the mean and median of each numeric column at each class grouping. Note the across function allows us to the same action (make and mean and median column) to multiple columns (the numeric ones).

yeast_data |> 
  select(c(-"seq_name", -"nuc")) |>
  group_by(class) |>
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), list(mean = mean, md = median)))

title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Load readxl and tidyverse library.

library(readxl)

Warning: package 'readxl' was built under R version 4.4.2

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.4.3


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 4.4.2


Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.4.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Load in white-wine excel data.

white_wine <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx")
white_wine

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 2              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
 3              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 4              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 5              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 6              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 7              62               0.32          0.16              7       0.045
 8               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 9              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
10              81               0.22          0.43              1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Extract column names from second sheet in excel file and use to rename the tibble’s column names.

wine_col_names <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx",
                             sheet = excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx")[2])
colnames(white_wine) <- as.matrix(wine_col_names)

Add column called type to indicate these wines are white

white_wine <- white_wine |>
  mutate(type = "white")

white_wine

# A tibble: 4,898 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Load readr library.

library(readr)

Load in read wine data.

red_wine <- read_delim("../red-wine.csv", delim = ";")

Rows: 1599 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ";"
dbl (12): fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlo...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

red_wine

# A tibble: 1,599 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7.4               0.7           0                 1.9     0.076
 2             7.8               0.88          0                 2.6     0.098
 3             7.8               0.76          0.04              2.3     0.092
 4            11.2               0.28          0.56              1.9     0.075
 5             7.4               0.7           0                 1.9     0.076
 6             7.4               0.66          0                 1.8     0.075
 7             7.9               0.6           0.06              1.6     0.069
 8             7.3               0.65          0                 1.2     0.065
 9             7.8               0.58          0.02              2       0.073
10             7.5               0.5           0.36              6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Replace the variable names with the same ones as above.

colnames(red_wine) <- as.matrix(wine_col_names)

red_wine <- red_wine |>
  mutate(type = "red")

red_wine

# A tibble: 1,599 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 2           7.8             0.88        0               2.6     0.098
 3           7.8             0.76        0.04            2.3     0.092
 4          11.2             0.28        0.56            1.9     0.075
 5           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 6           7.4             0.66        0               1.8     0.075
 7           7.9             0.6         0.06            1.6     0.069
 8           7.3             0.65        0               1.2     0.065
 9           7.8             0.58        0.02            2       0.073
10           7.5             0.5         0.36            6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Combine two data sets into one data set.

wine_data <- bind_rows(white_wine, red_wine)
wine_data

# A tibble: 6,497 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 6,487 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Filter combined data set for wines with quality greater than 6.5 and alcohol less than 132.

wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132)

# A tibble: 1,206 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1            66             0.16        0.4             1.5     0.044
 2            66             0.17        0.38            1.5     0.032
 3            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 4            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 5            64             0.31        0.38            2.9     0.038
 6            68             0.26        0.42            1.7     0.049
 7            72             0.32        0.36            2       0.033
 8            74             0.18        0.31            1.4     0.058
 9            66             0.25        0.29            1.1     0.068
10            62             0.16        0.33            1.1     0.057
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Continuing the chain, the data is sorted from highest to lowstest quality (descending order).

wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality))

# A tibble: 1,206 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45           10.6     0.035
 2            66             0.36        0.29            1.6     0.021
 3            74             0.24        0.36            2       0.031
 4            69             0.36        0.34            4.2     0.018
 5            71             0.26        0.49            2.2     0.032
 6            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 7            62             0.66        0.48            1.2     0.029
 8            68             0.26        0.42            1.7     0.049
 9            67             0.23        0.31            2.1     0.046
10            67             0.23        0.31            2.1     0.046
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Continuing the chain, we select the variables containing “acid”, alcohol, type, and quality.

wine_data |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) 

# A tibble: 1,206 × 6
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol type  quality
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104 white       9
 2            66             0.36        0.29     124 white       9
 3            74             0.24        0.36     125 white       9
 4            69             0.36        0.34     127 white       9
 5            71             0.26        0.49     129 white       9
 6            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8
 7            62             0.66        0.48     128 white       8
 8            68             0.26        0.42     105 white       8
 9            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8
10            67             0.23        0.31     107 white       8
# ℹ 1,196 more rows


Final addition to chain, for each value of the quality variable, calculate the mean and standard deviation of the alcohol as new columns.

wine_data |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, type, quality) |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  group_by(quality) |>
  mutate(across(alcohol, list(mean = mean, sd = sd)))

# A tibble: 1,206 × 8
# Groups:   quality [3]
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol type  quality alcohol_mean
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>        <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104 white       9        122.
